support.description: Content is actively maintained. Please report errors and inconsistencies

author_blurb.en: Translated for SuttaCentral by Bhikkhu Sujato, 2018. Dedicated to the public domain via Creative Commons Zero (CC0). You are encouraged to copy, reproduce, adapt, alter, or otherwise make use of this translation in any way you wish. Attribution is appreciated but not legally required.

segments.en: “Mendicants, dragons reproduce in these four ways.

segments.pli: Aṇḍajā nāgā, jalābujā nāgā, saṃsedajā nāgā, opapātikā nāgā.
segments.en: Dragons are born from an egg, from a womb, from moisture, or spontaneously.

segments.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, aṇḍajehi nāgehi jalābujā ca saṃsedajā ca opapātikā ca nāgā paṇītatarā.
segments.en: Of these, dragons born from a womb, from moisture, or spontaneously are better than those born from an egg.

segments.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, aṇḍajehi ca jalābujehi ca nāgehi saṃsedajā ca opapātikā ca nāgā paṇītatarā.
segments.en: Dragons born from moisture or spontaneously are better than those born from an egg or from a womb.

segments.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, aṇḍajehi ca jalābujehi ca saṃsedajehi ca nāgehi opapātikā nāgā paṇītatarā.
segments.en: Dragons born spontaneously are better than those born from an egg, from a womb, or from moisture.
These are the four ways that dragons reproduce.”

suttaplex.blurb: Dragons may be born from eggs, the womb, moisture, or spontaneously. Those born spontaneously are the best.
